headline.print_headline: The Joy of Feeding, Without All the Parental Angst
headline.main: The Joy of Feeding, Without All the Parental Angst

docs.abstract: Experts on child nutrition have begun to criticize age-old parental wisdom that hearty eating is always a good thing in infants, especially in environment of abundant food and rising obesity; one promising line of research involves training parents to recognize signals of hunger and satiety in their infants.
docs.lead_paragraph: While the number of obese babies is not on the rise, some of our standard infant feeding practices and attitudes may need revising.
docs.snippet: While the number of obese babies is not on the rise, some of our standard infant feeding practices and attitudes may need revising.

headline.main: Talking to Parents About Fat Babies

docs.abstract: Experts on child nutrition are debating whether some of the standard infant feeding practices and attitudes may be in need of revising, particularly the notion of getting infants to eat as much as possible.
docs.lead_paragraph: Obesity in teenagers and adolescents is a major concern for pediatricians. But the discussion gets tricky when it turns to a weight crisis in infants. As Dr. Perri Klass explains in this week's Science Times, experts on child nutrition are debating whether some of the standard infant feeding practices and attitudes may be in need of revising, particularly the notion of getting infants to eat as much as possible.
docs.snippet: Experts on child nutrition are debating whether some of the standard infant feeding practices and attitudes may be in need of revising, particularly the notion of getting infants to eat as much as possible.

headline.seo: A Fed Banker Wants to Break Up Some Banks

docs.abstract: Gretchen Morgenson Fair Game column holds that reducing the perils of gargantuan institutions — and the threat to taxpayers — is an idea that seems to be taking hold in Washington; cites Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas president Richard W Fisher's call for breaking up some enormous banks, and Sen Sherrod Brown's hearing on how to shield Main Street from what he calls megabank risk.
docs.lead_paragraph: Reducing the perils of gargantuan institutions — and the threat to taxpayers — is an idea that seems to be taking hold in Washington.
docs.snippet: Reducing the perils of gargantuan institutions — and the threat to taxpayers — is an idea that seems to be taking hold in Washington.

headline.seo: Muriel Petioni, Prominent Harlem Physician, Dies at 97
headline.print_headline: Muriel Petioni, 97, Prominent Harlem Physician, Dies
headline.main: Muriel Petioni, 97, Prominent Harlem Physician, Dies

docs.abstract: Muriel Petioni, prominent Harlem physician, dies at age 97.
docs.lead_paragraph: Called “the mother of medicine in Harlem,” Dr. Petioni was a leader of many community organizations promoting health care, housing development and education.
docs.snippet: Called “the mother of medicine in Harlem,” Dr. Petioni was a leader of many community organizations promoting health care, housing development and education.

headline.main: Cereal? Cookies? Oh, What's the Diff?

docs.abstract: Too many children are still being fed — and marketed — dessert disguised as breakfast.
docs.snippet: Too many children are still being fed — and marketed — dessert disguised as breakfast.

headline.main: Cereal? Cookies? Oh, What's the Diff?

docs.abstract: Too many children are still being fed - and marketed - dessert disguised as breakfast.
docs.lead_paragraph: We all know the importance of real food in the morning: kids who eat high-sugar breakfasts have a harder time in school, and a growing body of research suggests that foods sweetened with sugar or high-fructose corn syrup can be as addictive as nicotine or cocaine. It's clear, too, that for most of us the eating patterns we develop as children hang around forever.
docs.snippet: Too many children are still being fed - and marketed - dessert disguised as breakfast.
